title: Before 1 April 2018, will General Motors test an autonomous vehicle in New York City?
preds: If it hasn't happened, it's not going to happen on Easter Sunday...

I checked Cruise Automation's LinkedIn page for NYC employees and see only eight NYC based employees, a few of which might be located in San Fran and some of which were hired only one to two months ago - https://www.linkedin.com/search/results/people/?facetCurrentCompany=%5B%226577635%22%5D&facetGeoRegion=%5B%22us%3A70%22%5D&origin=FACETED_SEARCH Unclear whether they fully built out the NY office to enable a test
Lowering from 1% to 0% because seems unlikely they'd make the announcement on a holiday or Saturday.

No announcements made, and there is a lot that goes into the process of arranging such a test (http://www.gminsidenews.com/articles/autonomous-bolts-take-manhattan/), so seems very unlikely at this stage.
Deadline is 01.04.18 and no press releases from GM.

New York has strict test rules. Unlike other states, New York requires a State Police escort for every test vehicle, and there is a charge: A minimum of $92 per hour, plus 54 cents a mile.
In addition to a $5 million insurance policy on each vehicle, companies must in advance inform the state about each test’s date, time, sequence of roads and total routing distance down to nearest 1/10 of a mile.
April is coming up fast and no announcement.
Based on recent fatality record, and given the short time till 1 April, even if all technical safety issues are available and testable, this is not 'politically' feasible or advisable.
The first autonomous vehicle caused death will keep this from happening.
Adjusting my forecast to account for the remaining time and the recent fatality.
Lowering due to time frame and recent fatality optics

Pretty sure that the fatal accident in Arizona was not the car's fault and would have occurred with a human driver. But city streets are a greater risk for someone stepping in front of a speeding car. Not that a human would avoid an accident, but the problem with autonomous vehicles is that liability for all accidents is absorbed by one company (through its insurance payments), and people are more likely to sue, as they perceive that GM has deeper pockets than a random driver who hit a pedestrian.
Heavy snow in NY and extension of the timeframe make it highly unlikely that GM will run a test by March 30
Not after the Arizona fatality.  Not to say New York couldn't spare a few pedestrians....

Death of pedestrian (cyclist?) in Tempe, Arizona by Uber https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2018-03-19/uber-autonomous-car-involved-in-fatal-crash-in-arizona  I'm biased against Uber for so many reasons. Plus they kept a $6 charge on my credit card in the app rather than fully refunding it. So I just have a bad feeling about the greedy pricks. Sorry but I will dance a very happy jig if they fall over.  Smart cars should not be vacuuming up huge amounts of data from the public and selling it, either for profit or to subsidise their glorified taxi service.  So I'm not surprised about this stupid incompetence that should be tested on highways first for millions of hours and billions of miles or 10 years a least before it's allowed on suburban streets. So it's good that NYC will probably postpone this for (I'm guessing) 6 to 12 months!  Classic case study of being so greedy and growing too fast. They could have been nice and just settled for some simple airport shuttle run style service testing in low populated cities with bus lanes, but nooo they want those sweet greenbacks for the vulture capitalists.  I hope London kicks them out too. 
/end rant ;-P

Self-driving Uber car kills Arizona woman crossing street
https://www.reuters.com/article/us-autos-selfdriving-uber/self-driving-uber-car-kills-arizona-woman-crossing-street-idUSKBN1GV296 Stop those demon cars now! Before they kill again!
I was pretty optymistic on chances of testing during NY autoshow but after Uber accident I do not believe they will do.
I was at 1%... taking down to 0% as per others (autonomous Uber incident in Arizona killed pedestrian)

No way they'll start up in NYC in the next two weeks after the Uber crash in Arizona... Self-driving Uber vehicle strikes and kills pedestrian
https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/dr-gridlock/wp/2018/03/19/uber-halts-autonomous-vehicle-testing-after-a-pedestrian-is-struck/

Per link, chances of a NYC test occurring before 4/1/18 would appear greatly lowered. (Perhaps in spite of some actual details of the fatal Tempe crash.) http://money.cnn.com/2018/03/19/technology/uber-autonomous-car-fatal-crash/index.html

-40.  Knee jerk reaction to uber death http://www.bbc.com/news/business-43459156.  Slight possibility they will try to show case their technology as superior, but the lawyers will be king over engineers right now.
I think the fatality caused by the Uber self-driving car in Arizona last night will push this back --if there were indeed plans to test.
Not Chevy or GM per se, but relatable none-the-less.  https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2018-03-19/uber-is-pausing-autonomous-car-tests-in-all-cities-after-fatality

Waymo, the driverless car comp. from Alphabet, is testing fully autonomous cars in Arizona and California. Lyft and Nutonomy are testing in Boston. Uber is running a pilot program in Pittsburgh. GM said in January that their driverless fleet could be ready by 2019; testing in downtown New York City would move the company to the top of the pack, but they won't do it it there's any risk of failure.  Cruise Automation (GM self-driving unit) hasn't tweeted since early January. Saw CEO, Kyle Vogt, interviewed by Bloomberg. He acknowledged there is a race to be the first but  emphasized his company is interested in building a long term, sustainable business.  Not interested in being first to do a demonstration but in building a sustainable business, he said.   Didn't sound to me like they're gearing towwards testing in NYC in two weeks, but then again this interview is from beginning of January.  Vogt himself talked about AlphaGo and AlphaZero during the interview, saying "human level performance just a stop along the way."  Who knows how fast this technology is moving. During interview, Vogt said company is growing pretty quickly already have 450 people working, adding many more.  
"It will be ready when it's ready but right now we think it's 2019." He was asked what "ready" and he said it's a production vehicle in a major urban area" To see interview go here: https://www.youtube.com/watch?time_continue=322&v=FwcoWJ5VSac Will reduce forecast until I find a better indicator.

As Hammer-Time mentioned, I to had the concern of them pulling a PR stunt at the beginning of the show, but Chevy doesn't even have a press conference scheduled:  https://www.autoshowny.com/press/#/press-conferences
They may still attempt this for NY auto show, but I doubt it. Too much downside. I admit bias - hate GM for killing Saab.

Passage of time update. Watching for any info. about possible autonomous GM test in association with the 3/30/18 (start of the) New York Auto Show. 
..None found yet.
With two weeks remaining, it is highly unlikely that GM will test AV vehicles in New York. In public messages, GM now speaks much less to their plans to test AVs in New York in early 2018.
There are only roughly two weeks left and from what I see the other forecasters commenting/predicting there is no signal for public plans to test in the coming days.

The law, which passed early this year, only allows a brief window for autonomous vehicle testing before expiring on April 1st, 2018.  Woody Allen says 85% of life is just showing up. GM will show up. No one wants to miss this opportunity.

Update:  GM investing $100 million into facilities for building self-driving cars
https://venturebeat.com/2018/03/15/gm-pours-100-million-into-facilities-for-building-self-driving-cars/?utm_source=dlvr.it&utm_medium=twitter "General Motors said on Thursday it will invest more than $100 million in two facilities as it prepares to build production versions of its Cruise self-driving car next year at its Orion Township assembly plant in Michigan. 
In January, GM filed a petition seeking U.S. government approval for a fully autonomous car – one without a steering wheel, brake pedal or accelerator pedal – to enter the automaker’s first commercial ride-sharing fleet in 2019." @Daveinsea pointed out that "So far no extension on licence for testing which expires April 1. Just a test will work. And, they have licence, rented a space in Manhattan and the show [NY Auto Show which runs from March 30 to April 8] is the end of the month."
No updates on this. Doesn't seem like it's happening before April 1.
Even if they had planned to, the weather has been beastly there and nobody is driving anything anywhere unless they absolutely have to.

It's not really fair to make a prediction this close to the deadline, but the lack of chatter about the test between Nov 1, 2017 and now makes one believe it will not happen.  _IF_ they do, it will be a relatively simple route that manages to somehow miss complex intersections like Times Square, Columbus Circle and Delancy and Essex.
Its very unlikely as the streets are highly complex and the regulations stricter, GM is more likely to go with simple roads and lower regulated spaces

Thank you bcamerin for the info re NY state extension on autonomous testing to 2020. Maybe GM will pull off a one-time test for NYC Auto show - but need to balance fallout if something happens (even if autonomous vehicle not at fault).
They are not quite there yet and the weather is unpredictable
no way.  Manhattan traffic-environment makes SanFran look like a country village
Passage of time update, plus Cuomo AV-testing extension article cited in comment below.
Nobody is going out in this weather, with or without General Motors....
Dropping to zero because I can't find any news or developments about this and the deadline for the question is in three or so weeks.
Mayor Cuomo's new budget asks for an extension to the AV testing program http://www.govtech.com/fs/automation/New-Yorks-Cuomo-Wants-to-Extend-AV-Testing.html
General Motors is a Car Company, not an AI company.
time up date no news is good news ...

Most testing of these vehicles is being done in the west. I believe this agency will wait for more intel from those markets and test in other high-density areas with a low profile before moving to NYC.   NYC is a highly visible market that would be a disastrous location for any type of failure.  Of course, "testing" could be performed at a very low volume traffic time in a lower density area of NYC, technically serving as a "test" case.
NYC drivers are most likely to mess with autonomous vehicles by aggressive driving.

Interesting information in the forecasts below. Forecasts are all over the place. Reasons why to forecast Yes:
- Announced timeline by GM
- NY law to allow this expires 4/1
- NYC auto show 3/31 for publicity purposes
- GM had to go through trouble of arranging police escort, paying for it, and insuring vehicle for $5 million, a substantial investment
- They only need to test one vehicle one time to get the publicity benefit and make this a Yes Reasons why to forecast No:
- Complex NYC is one of the most congested cities in the world, could lead to balking / desire for more testing elsewhere
- Not the end of the world if GM doesn't make their timeline
- Strong organized labor in NYC could lodge a last-second challenge
- Timelines have been frequently missed in the past by autonomous testers It's a crapshoot, really. I think it will happen because they only have to test one vehicle to get the publicity benefits and losing the permit / legal environment might cause a missed opportunity. I know I'm going against the grain here because the initial forecast average has dipped from 70% to 25%, but I think a company like GM would greatly benefit from the publicity of testing even one vehicle in NYC.
For sure it's going to happen, but I don't think by April 1st:  https://tribecacitizen.com/2018/02/26/self-driving-cars-are-coming-to-lower-manhattan/

The petition for tests on Cruise AV has been sent to the department of transportation, this means GM is ready to start testing. Probability now relies on how fast can this permit be achieved by the company, but latest Conference call suggested petition has been made quite recently.
It's obvious due to the latest public announcements by GM.

Time is growing short (for this question), but the following 2/26/18 article claims "Cruise Automation" has leased building space in lower Manhattan. No vehicle testing dates were available via the article. Slight 'bump' upward to forecast for the time being, but only about a month left here. https://tribecacitizen.com/2018/02/26/self-driving-cars-are-coming-to-lower-manhattan/
4/1 approaching... no media update, nothing on their twitter, nothing on their website since the initial announcement of intent back in Oct 2017
If they test they will do it during or just before NYC Auto show that is starting 3/30.

almost all vehicle accidents reported in CA in 2017 are GM Cruze - so they are doing a lot of testing but also high # of reported AV accidents (although not enough data available to understand accident rate).  Seems tech may not be ready to test in complex NYC environment, esp with potential loss of signals due to building density
My answer is based solely on perceived probability. Many auto makers are pushing for “live” tests in high density areas. GM is not an exception
GM is well on its way
Time is running out. NYT of 1/12 still only announces.
They need publicity to boost image vs Tesla. The
Lowering due to passage of time.  4/1 is not far away.
regulatory hurdles/time elasping since last forecast
If the court case on the accident with the motorcyclist goes their way and the delays being filed can be stopped there’s a very slight possibility.
It's hard to imagine a safe and useful driverless vehicle for NYC.

passage of time - bill still in ways and means/finance. Want to look at language regarding effective date of legislation again. If effective immediately upon approval, then that is the date the state police would no longer need to, presumably, escort vehicles. That would be a regulatory and operational/testing environment closer to San Francisco. I suppose it's possible they're just waiting for a more favorable testing environment vis-a-vis no police escort which would interfere with real world testing. Might they pull the trigger and roll out the cars the next day upon the bill passing? Who knows. If not effective upon approval and only effective as of the original expiration date, then police escorts are presumed to continue to be required up to April 1 thus keeping the less favorable testing environment.
Luxury cars are expected to have self driving functions during near term market cycles. Cadillac will need the publicity of testing a vehicle in New York city
They will first test extensively in low population areas.  I doubt they are ready for that kind of congestion.
They have a permit that expires on this date.  They plan on releasing vehicles with no steering wheel or pedals next year.  Ill be optomistic now and revise later.

On the one hand, GM has done well in this space (buying “Cruise” supercharged their efforts), weather is looking good for test runs, and upcoming NYC auto show would be good place to show this off. On the other hand you want to get it right - failing while it may drag all autonomous cars down, will impact GM most. The info doesn’t even have to be correct - fake news(!) like recent motorcycle incident. Throw in NYC pedestrians and cabbies and you have a very challenging environment. Like other companies in this space GM has provided clear goals but vague updates - and most have missed their timelines.
Very limited interest on GM to go all out with electric and AI ideas

I think GM will begin testing their Cruise autonomous vehicles in NYC in 2018. That said, I think that April is too soon; at the investor conference in Detroit, GM was more guarded regarding the timing of Cruise testing in NYC. GM had previously suggested that NYC testing would begin in early 2018. I think that the answer to this question may depend, in part, on how to define “test”. Would a single test drive of a Cruise vehicle count? I think so.
Chances will increase that GM will test autonomous vehicle in NYC as more (successful) data from other pilot cities are collected.  Possibly later in 2018.

http://www.thedrive.com/video/18524/watch-cadillacs-amazing-no-hands-super-cruise-in-action.  "driving on the northbound saw mill parkway".  https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Saw_Mill_River_Parkway.  The Saw Mill River Parkway is inventoried by the New York State Department of Transportation (NYSDOT) as New York State Route 987D (NY 987D), an unsigned reference route designation.  This starts right on the edge of NYC as far as I can tell
.., so is a just miss.  Impressive stuff, and close to going in New York City.  let's see.
Driverless cars are big in the news these days and all sorts of companies are trying to cash in on the technology. GM is a major player in the industry so of course they will try.
They already got their press release. No one will remember if they fail to demonstrate. Such announcements will be a dime a dozen by April anyway..

Aside from California, as of Feb 2018 cars are being test driven in Pittsburgh, Detroit, Chicago, and just starting in Washington DC. New York may follow suit if results from other cities are positive and accidents are minimal. Other constraints include: 1) getting regulatory approval/permits; 2) possible political opposition from labor group who want to get ahead of a job threat (which they are good at doing in NYC). Increased likelihood by 3rd quarter 2018.
Lowering forecast for now, per orchidny comment below plus general lack of recent info./reports relating to this question
Dropping a good amount because I haven't read or heard anything about this project in months.

The GM self-driving cruise AV car was on public display ahead of the Detroit auto show in mid January.  Also in early January, GM filed a request with the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration to deploy the car. http://www.detroitnews.com/story/business/autos/detroit-auto-show/2018/01/17/gm-self-driving-fleet-car-debuts/109557490/ This article from Feb. 6 says GM will start testing in NYC "later in the year" http://www.whec.com/news/self-driving-cars-is-rochester-ready/4774758/ But just yesterday, Feb. 12:  "Senate Hits the Brakes on Self-Driving Car Legislation Over Safety Concerns"
http://observer.com/2018/02/senate-self-driving-car-legislation-safety-concerns/ "Legislation to remove regulatory obstacles in driverless car development is stalling in the Senate. The bipartisan AV Start Act would allow developers to test and market autonomous vehicles immediately—even though detailed federal safety regulations will take years to write.
AV Start Act from passing in the House and getting approved by the Senate Commerce Committee. The Trump administration also supports the legislation. 
The bill would also block states from adopting safety regulations more stringent than the federal standard (once that standard is adopted)." 
An April date might be too soon.
they're not paying off enough regulators.

New York is extremely difficult to drive in and it is notoriously litigious and nature. It seems for more likely that they will test this vehicle in other markets before they attempt to do this in the New York Market.
I think GM is at the bottom of the totem pole when it comes to  Confirming the technology to do so.

Renewing my 5% chance. While I agree with peers pointing out need to test before April 1st (April Fools!) and potential changes to frameworks...I also agree with others that (1) there has been very little follow up (2) as a regular visitor to NYC, Kamikaze drivers may not yield results to brag about (3) suggest general public doesn’t care/follow these things closely. However NYC Auto Show is coming up - that would be an ideal time to brag/launch. Not doing so really is no loss of face IMO for GM. 
I welcome our robotic overlords, but they’re not quite ready for prime time.

Law in New York good til April 1st. I admit that the chances are going down fast. But, sometimes I make seemingly illogical calls. https://www.theverge.com/2017/10/17/16488330/gm-cruise-nyc-self-driving-car-test-cuomo
The law, which passed early this year, only allows a brief window for autonomous vehicle testing before expiring on April 1st, 2018.
https://taas.technology/abstracts
https://www.google.com/url?sa=t&source=web&rct=j&url=http://www.ncsl.org/Portals/1/Documents/transportation/STLS_UC_Davis_Connected_Mobility_31646.pdf&ved=2ahUKEwiH5a3ak57ZAhUGzFMKHaE8Ck8QFjAFegQIDRAB&usg=AOvVaw33MZoS9fIXmpbvPiy1pjmm
https://www.google.com/url?sa=t&source=web&rct=j&url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/samabuelsamid/2018/01/09/ford-ceo-hackett-talks-about-the-business-of-automated-driving-at-ces/amp/&ved=2ahUKEwiH5a3ak57ZAhUGzFMKHaE8Ck8QFjAGegQIBxAB&usg=AOvVaw3LzhiFA7viv8ANmiCY48tm&ampcf=1
Kamikaze NY driving is not a testing ground for good PR if anything goes awry! Try North Las Vegas .....better, flatter, longer strait roads, and less traffic, gambling is accepted!
Time has passed without any news so I lower my prediction.

GM has been testing autonomous vehicles for years, and many have seen increasing amounts of competition in their various segments. In order to remain competitive, more data and successful tests are needed to establish GM as an autonomous vehicle manufacturer. The regulations pose the most significant threat to the plan, but GM is a well-capitalized business. They will be able to work it out.

Market competition indicates consumers have a growing interest in these vehicles. Companies are scrambling to develop technology and field testing has already been approved in at least one state. New York is very progressive. The time frame of 18 months suggests that there is ample time for GM to get in the game.

Back in December, Cruise's website had a few listings for open positions in New York, including those of autonomous vehicle trainers. As of today, there are no open positions in NYC. While this could mean they've filled the positions, the fact that I couldn't find any news about any of their activities in NYC suggests it's more likely they've postponed their plans.
They will most likely wait for consistent and dry weather, which April and May do not offer.

GM has announced that it is doing so, and it has the technological capacity generally.  The questions I have are: (1) is it worth it given New York's extraordinarily high regulatory hurdle; (2) is the threat of a high profile accident higher in New York (probably not); (3)is there enough time between now and 1 April; (4) are New York City streets and weather so much more challenging that this is actually a significantly different technical hurdle?  It would be useful to have data on how often GM, Waymo, and others actually follow through on their forecasts.  Part of me wants to say, 'well, they say they're going to do it, and they can do it, so 100%.'

GM has stated it's commitment and intent to testing in NYC. The window of opportunity given by the state is short as well. It's now or never. Fulfilling their commitment will give them an advantage over competitors. I expect the company will proceed as officially stated.
With the increasing interest in self-driving vehicles, NYC seems like the logical next test bed after Silicon Valley.
haven't heard that they won't so I guess we're getting 1%/month closer to that day
If they do this this year, they will roll it out in the summer.  Not before the first week of June.
General Motors will wait until there is no chance of snow or storms for a first test of their autonomous vehicle concept.
Big jump down on Mary Barra's comment on the Q4 earnings call regarding launch in NYC. They are continuing to focus on SF and still mapping NYC. Sounds like a punt. Bill is still in committee.

I'm tempted to raise back to 70 on the confirmatory report expressed in the article, "...GM is testing in a demanding city environment in San Francisco, and plans to expand to Manhattan as soon as the current quarter," but I think for now doing so would only be a move influenced by confirmation bias. The bigger factor that has me thinking of raising is how the rest of article discusses the pace at which GM has been closing the gap in the autonomous space - though they admit to being bullish on GM in the past. I believe the core of what I'm thinking about most with respect to this question and the timeline is just how aggressively they'll pursue closing the gap. Holding for now but with a upward outlook.  3 February 2018
https://www.barrons.com/articles/gm-gets-back-in-the-fast-lane-1517624680

There is a lot riding on this event and General Motors has cooperated with both the state and city authorities to achieve their goal.  The city and state are happy with GM's compliance I really think this will happen before the deadline
I understand autonomous vehicle technology and NYC regulation environment

Not ready yet? Dateline 1-31-2018 Waymo’s 0.18 disengagements per 1,000 miles compares with 0.8 for GM, which improved from a rate of about 18 during the year-earlier period. The companies’ 2017 reports to California’s Department of Motor Vehicles span the 12 months ending in November.  Cruise Chief Executive Officer Kyle Vogt wrote in an October blog entry that GM is testing in dense urban environments including San Francisco to put its cars through tougher challenges, while other companies stick to easier-to-navigate suburban streets. “Our vehicles encounter challenging (and often absurd) situations up to 46 times more often than other places self-driving cars are tested,” Vogt wrote. “Perhaps for this reason, nobody else is regularly testing self-driving cars in SF.”-- https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2018-01-31/waymo-robot-cars-need-little-human-help-as-gm-s-make-big-leap

Moving down a couple points on the motorcycle crash [1] - others have already pointed it out [2] - but I may have been too dismissive.  It's not the first crash the vehicles have had and the article suggests GM is working through the data from the vehicle, but it may be that they're triple checking systems. [1] https://www.popsci.com/self-driving-car-crashes-blame-game#page-2
[2] http://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/679964

thank you to @thefourtheye and @September.  I wish you would be right, and i can agree on many points, however i have changed my judgement for the simple reason of the question’s deadline, the  1. April.  I am a pragmatic operational guy and upon my judgement, time-span is getting too short for such testing .
March 30 - April 8 is NYC Auto Show. Keeping it low even though this would make a splash.

While some last minute hiccup might prevent a test GM has said it will test and given the window for testing closes in April it seems likely they will follow through with the statement or risk embarrassment over a back down (it is unlikely they would have made the claim in the first place if they thought they couldn't overcome the tech challenges in time)
https://www.theverge.com/2017/10/17/16488330/gm-cruise-nyc-self-driving-car-test-cuomo

In my quest chasing down the status of autonomous testing in the state since the allowance was announced on 10 May 2017 [1], I found that Audi was was the first application to be approved as of 31 May 2017 [2] and was the first to conduct a demonstration in the state on 13 June 2017 [3]. Two manufacturers are known to have tested in the NY state [4]:     • Audi
        ○ June - mentioned above     • Cadillac - a GM brand by the way
        ○ June - Cadillac SUV on University of Buffalo Campus roads.
        ○ September - multiple Cadillac CT6s; embarked on a coast-to-coast test; OFFICIALLY THE FIRST TIME VEHICLES WERE TESTED IN NYC. A few things stand out to me:
1. Applications for these incumbent automakers appear to be fast tracked. We don't have approval dates for Cadillac or Cruise, but all the press around Cruise's application seem to imply that approval was a slam dunk. I'd been working on the assumption that it was approved, but it would still be nice to see some confirmation just to check my six. It could be that Kyle Vogt's thank you to Gov. Cuomo [5] was premature, but given all that's been happening since, I'd say approval is a safe assumption.
2. Execution by incumbents is fast. Audi tested within 2 weeks of approval. Can't say when Cadillac was approved.
3. Cruise is not GM's first rodeo with regard to testing in the state. They also already have experience with one of their brands testing in NYC under the current legislation which required "direct supervision" by the state police.
4. You've got to dig for this information. I would have expected some of this to be covered more heavily in the press, but I've found surprisingly little. Another example outside of NY would be Waymo's winter testing in Michigan [6]. There was a bit of fanfare in the beginning, but so little since that it's rather inferential. Moving back up a bit for now. [1] https://www.governor.ny.gov/news/governor-cuomo-announces-autonomous-vehicle-testing-begin-new-york-state
[2] https://www.governor.ny.gov/news/governor-cuomo-announces-approval-first-application-autonomous-vehicle-demonstration-new-york
[3] http://www.governor.ny.gov/news/governor-cuomo-announces-first-successful-autonomous-vehicle-demonstrations-new-york-state
[4] http://www.governor.ny.gov/news/governor-cuomo-announces-cruise-automation-applying-begin-first-fully-autonomous-vehicle
[5] https://twitter.com/kvogt/status/920312043776778240
[6] http://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/681390

Down a bit on: PROPOSED LEGISLATION JANUARY 2018
legislation moving through NY legislature that would remove the requirement that state police directly supervise all autonomous vehicle testing and extend testing to 1 April 2020 - though they've also built in an automatic renewal at that time [1]. It was referred to the Ways and Means committee on 18 Jan 2018. So, in light of this new evidence how likely is it that they would extend their testing time frame, given that the law had originally been set to expire in April with a report deadline of 1 March? I've found no evidence that the DMV March deadline has moved and I don't expect it to even if the amended legislation passes because in both current and proposed legislation, the commissioner of motor vehicles is required to submit a report on autonomous vehicle demonstrations or tests conducted in the state before 1 June. They may not care whether they've conducted a test so that the commissioner can report on it. But does give them some breathing room. I'd still call it "early 2018" if they tested any time in April, but that's subjective. It would also release them from "direct supervision" from the state police - whatever that consists of - so it does relax their testing environment in that regard. Linked In now shows Cruise Automation has a Community and Government Relations liason who started this month. Perhaps this is a sign of imminent testing, perhaps it's a sign of eventual testing. Perhaps an argument could be made that holding to the original - and still current - legislative timelineIn either case, I'm interpreting it as support for my previous assumption that previously posted jobs on Cruise's career page were filled rather than simply removed. Other employees have conflicting data regarding actual work location/geographic scope of work. TO DO: THINK ABOUT MY CONFIDENCE INTERVAL GIVEN THE TIME FRAME. KEEP DIGGING. I wonder how fast things move through the NY legislature? [1] http://assembly.state.ny.us/leg/?bn=A09508&term=2017
[2] original as on NY DMV website: https://dmv.ny.gov/forms/autonomousvehiclelaw.pdf -----------------------------------------------
UPDATE: 28 January 2018. I neglected to mention that the NY Senate version of the bill, which is linked to the bill in [1] above, is also in committee (Finance). I also checked out the NY Assembly's Yellow Book which examines the proposed 2018-2019 Fiscal Year budget. It too mentions the modification to make permanent  the allowance for autonomous demonstrations and testing. [3] [3] http://nyassembly.gov/Reports/WAM/2018yellow/2018files/2018yellowbook.pdf
While I believe it to be possible for GM to test a driverless car in NYC, I believe that regulatory hurdles will keep this from happening within the given time frame.

Still bullish on this. Some good points have been raised with respect to consequences, namely the lack thereof, for the competition, namely Tesla. (http://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/679014). That's certainly good consolation and ripe for the GM folks to rationalize any failure to test in NYC by April 1. Perhaps a bit of a counterpoint to that, however, is that by executing their NYC initiative by April 1 - or perhaps by March 1 depending on whether you view the DMV report requirement as a functional deadline - they prove that they can execute rapid development and deploy in spite of the challenges in doing so. I'd say they are motivated enough to do it as it would be a central point of differentiation aimed directly at Tesla's inability to hit targets and deadlines. GM has set an aggressive goal for introducing the Cruise into the fleet by 2019. Testing in NYC would help them get there, particularly from an experiential data perspective - though NHSTA and similar federal bodies still need to be navigated. Time to dig deep for disconfirming signals to my bullish forecast. 2017

After being optimistic for quite some time,  I see the  time melting. I don’t think a test can be conducted seriously and sufficiently in now less than 2.5 months. To me, this becomes now the key argument for, if a test will be executed, yes or no.

GM said in November that it expected to transport people and cargo with self-driving vehicles in big cities sometime in 2019. Since acquiring Cruise Automation, a San Francisco startup, in spring 2016, GM and Cruise have developed four generations of autonomous Chevrolet Bolt EVs. But the last version has no steering wheel, and no pedals for accelerating or braking. Doors open and close automatically. Those functions are handled by software, sensors and a laser-guidance technology called LiDAR. Seven states, including Michigan, allow such vehicles to be tested with federal approval. The other six are North Carolina, Tennessee, Georgia, Texas, Colorado and Nevada. But before a vehicle can transport people, it must meet a battery of standards set by the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration. The legal problem is that those standards require compliance through tests with a human driver as well as manual steering, acceleration and braking controls. Leading this journey through the regulatory process is Paul Hemmersbaugh, former NHTSA general counsel who resigned from the agency a year ago to join GM as chief counsel and policy director for transportation as a service. "We are asking NHTSA to give us permission to meet the safety standards through a different approach because we can’t achieve them now without a human driver or steering wheel," said Hemmersbaugh. "When you don’t have a steering wheel it makes no sense to talk about an air bag in the steering wheel." Read more:  GM: Driverless cars can be affordable and profitable General Motors' Cruise Automation aims to test self-driving cars in New York City But here's another challenge: NHTSA has had no chief since former administrator Mark Rosekind left in November 2016. In April he was hired by Zoox, a San Francisco autonomous technology firm, as chief safety innovation officer.   For the last year, Jack Danielson, a career civil servant and fourth in the agency's chain of command, has run NHTSA. Many key vacancies, including permanent chief counsel, director for government affairs and chief financial officer have not been filled. It is unclear how that will impact the review.

I think this is very likely as the law authorizing autonomous vehicles will expire April 1. The reason I'm not at 100% is because de Blasio seems to be very against autonomous vehicles and he may be able to stop/slow the roll out.

The NYS law permitting autonomous vehicle testing in NYC expires 4/1/18. Applications must be submitted before 3/1/18. Cars are required to have drivers behind the wheel in case of emergencies, pass all NYS and US safety requirements, and have a $5 million insurance policy. Applications also need to detail the date/time of the test and include details such as origin, destination, sequence of roads, and distance. Basically, testing will be very prescribed. With Waymo close to becoming the first to the market, I believe GM will be pressured to conduct a high density urban test both for publicity and to distinguish itself from its competitors. Given the difficulties in driving in Manhattan, I predict that permission will be granted to GM to test in one of the less congested areas of NYC, possibly upper Manhattan or the outer Boros, and likely on a weekend.

Cuomo are having a dumb argument over allowing self-driving cars in Lower Manhattan, though they may be inadvertently showing why we need such things: Getting emotion out of lots of areas of life, from governing to driving, would be a nice improvement. Last week, Cuomo announced General Motors is applying to test autonomous vehicles in Gotham next year. No one told the mayor, and he wasn’t pleased when he found out. “It’s a mistake . . . It creates a danger. We are going to work vigorously to stop it,” he said.
